text: [Music]
you know when I started doing this about
10 years ago in London and when I first
started this job I used to literally
make lists of people on Wall Street that
I wanted to try to meet um every given
month so I would sit and make a list of
30 people and I would cold call
literally and
um introduce myself as a reporter who
planned to be on the beat for a very
long time and thought it was important
that we get to know each other in some
way and um I think hopefully over the
years people have um a taken those calls
and occasionally those meetings and a
trust uh level has developed and I think
that's probably true of any uh reporter
um it's really about
uh
hard work she leather reporting getting
on the telephone running around to in my
cases to meetings or events to see
different people and uh whispering in
their ear and hopefully they're going to
Whisper back uh and and tell you the
information U you know as a child I
always enjoyed uh my parents used to
have these little cocktail parties and I
I always loved trying to get the adults
to tell me things they weren't supposed
to say and in many ways that's what my
job is today it's getting people to tell
many things that they probably are
otherwise not supposed to say and I
think you do that by developing some
semblance of
trust that you're that you're going to
be fair and and and that you that you
get it I think that's part of it I've
tried to study the industry I've spent
enormous amounts of time I can
unfortunately do a Model A DCF model
with the best of them I wouldn't say I
enjoy it but
and I also think that when You' studied
it up when you when you come to the
table with the right questions when it's
clear to the other side of to the
interviewee that you know what you're
talking about you can get a lot
more I think the hardest part for
financial journalists going
forward is actually going to be to get a
straight
take um it's very hard hard to truly get
close to the action anymore um I think
there was a sense in the 80s and maybe
even part of the
90s um and
earlier when you could
really get the CEO on the phone any day
um you could you could really get inside
the story but
today um most of these companies are
pretty lawyered up they have a PR
apparatus it's very
hard in real time
to actually get a story that hasn't come
pre-spun
and while the government is requiring
more and more disclosures as we've seen
some of these disclosures are worthless
and so it makes it uh it makes it makes
it an enormous challenge to be able
to to really be able to spot the
problems um when when I'm aware that
they're out to lunch my goal is usually
to tell you that they're out to lunch
um I I can't promise I've I've gotten it
right every
time that's a terrific question because
unfortunately in the world of sort of
Wall Street
prognosticators they only happen to to
be right once or twice so right now nuel
rabini for example who called the crisis
seems to be the guy that you'd want to
hear from or Meredith Whitney who told
you that City group was uh in trouble
would be somebody you'd want to spend
time to and listen to and and perhaps
quote in an
article but other people would suggest
to you that they were making these
Arguments for six or seven or eight
years and had you been quoting them then
you most people would have told you they
were absolutely and wildly wrong so it's
actually a complicated issue because
some of these people will look right and
be right for the moment and then won't
be right for a very long time
again
Financial
television played a remarkably large
role as the medium with which people
were receiving their information during
this crisis this was probably the first
televised financial crisis that existed
and some people have blamed TV uh for
the crisis or for speeding up the
crisis and there might be some truth to
that in that as journalists who are
trying to reflect what's happening in
the market it gets reflected back and
and this sort of mirror gets mirrored
back and forth and back and forth and
there's a personalization to it TV as a
medium is so different than reading a
headline that's saying there's a problem
but when you're sitting in your office
especially when it's about yourself or
about a firm that you're trading with
and you're hearing and seeing another
individual tell you these folks are in
trouble it really can
exacerbate uh the situation that's not
to say that I think all these people
were doing reporting irresponsibly there
were some reports that were wrong here
and there but for the most part I must
say even having finished this book I
watched uh a lot of TV uh tapes during
this period and most of the stuff
actually stood up quite well much better
than I suspect many people would want to
acknowledge
